description: From Middle English haven, from Old English hafian, habban (“to have”), from Proto-West Germanic *habbjan, from Proto-Germanic *habjaną (“to have”), durative of *habjaną (“to lift, take up”), from Proto-Indo-European *kh₂pyéti, present tense of *keh₂p- (“to take, seize, catch”). Related to heave.

Since there is no common Indo-European root for a transitive possessive verb have (notice that Latin habeō is not etymologically related to English have), Proto-Indo-European probably lacked the have structure. Instead, the third person forms of be were used, with the possessor in dative case, compare Latin mihi est / sunt, literally to me is / are.

entries.meaning: (usually contrastive) A wealthy or privileged person.
examples: A good credit rating can mean the difference between being a have or a have not.

entries.meaning: (uncommon) One who has some (contextually specified) thing.
examples: Generally, I can assure you that a woman's posterior causes a stir, whether she's considered a have or a have not. But in most cases, men gravitate toward a pair of prominent gluteus muscles because they find this display appealing. This prominent protrusion can make a pair of jeans look like it was painted on, above just being good to look at. And by the way, it also incites some backshot (a Caribbean term for a well-known sex position) and spanking tendencies during sexual activity ...

verbs.description: have (third-person singular simple present has, present participle having, simple past and past participle had)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To possess, own.
examples: I have a house and a car.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hold, as something at someone's disposal.
examples: Look what I have here—a frog I found on the street!
Do you have the key? (not necessarily one's own key)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To include as a part, ingredient, or feature.
examples: The stove has a handle. The shirt has sleeves.
The words cow and dog have three letters.
A government has three branches: the executive, legislative, and judicial.
The movie has lots of action.

entries.meaning: (transitive) Used to state the existence or presence of someone in a specified relationship with the subject.
examples: I have two sisters.
She doesn’t have any friends.
I have a really mean boss.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To consume or use up (a particular substance or resource, especially food or drink).
examples: I have breakfast at six o'clock.
You've already had five drinks!
She's had more than enough time already.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To undertake or perform (an action or activity).
examples: Can I have a look at that?
He's having a tantrum about it.
I’m going to have a bath now.
Let’s have a game of tiddlywinks.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be scheduled to attend, undertake or participate in.
examples: What class do you have right now? I have English.
Fred won’t be able to come to the party; he has a meeting that day.
I have a lot of work to do.

entries.meaning: To experience, go through, undergo.
examples: We had a hard year last year, with the locust swarms and all that.
He had surgery on his hip yesterday.
I’m having the time of my life!
I hope you have a wonderful birthday.
This year we're having Christmas with my wife's family in Thunder Bay.

entries.meaning: To be afflicted with, suffer from.
examples: He had a cold last week.

entries.meaning: (auxiliary verb, taking a past participle) Used in forming the perfect aspect.
examples: I have already eaten today.
I had already eaten.
I will have left by the time you get here.

entries.meaning: Used as an interrogative verb before a pronoun to form a tag question, echoing a previous use of 'have' as an auxiliary verb or, in certain cases, main verb. (For further discussion, see the appendix English tag questions.)
examples: They haven’t eaten dinner yet, have they?
Your wife hasn’t been reading that nonsense, has she?
He has some money, hasn’t he?

entries.meaning: (auxiliary verb, taking a to-infinitive) See have to.
examples: I have to go.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give birth to.
examples: The couple always wanted to have children.
My wife is having the baby right now!
My mother had me when she was 25.

entries.meaning: (usually passive) To obtain.
examples: The substance you describe can't be had at any price.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To engage in sexual intercourse with.
examples: He’s always bragging about how many women he’s had.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To accept as a romantic partner.
examples: Despite my protestations of love, she would not have me.

entries.meaning: (transitive with bare infinitive) To cause to, by a command, request or invitation.
examples: They had me feed their dog while they were out of town.
Her very boyfriend is the person the criminal has do most of her dirty deeds.

entries.meaning: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To cause to be.
examples: He had him arrested for trespassing.
The lecture’s ending had the entire audience in tears.
Jim has his eyes closed.

entries.meaning: (transitive with bare infinitive) To be affected by an occurrence. (Used in supplying a topic that is not a verb argument.)
examples: The hospital had several patients contract pneumonia last week.
I’ve had three people today tell me my hair looks nice.

entries.meaning: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To depict as being.
examples: Their stories differed; he said he’d been at work when the incident occurred, but her statement had him at home that entire evening.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang) To defeat in a fight; take.
examples: I could have him!

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang) To inflict punishment or retribution on.
examples: You broke the window! Teacher’ll have you for that!

entries.meaning: (dated outside Ireland) To be able to speak (a language).
examples: I have no German.

entries.meaning: To feel or be (especially painfully) aware of.
examples: Dan certainly has arms today, probably from scraping paint off four columns the day before.

entries.meaning: (informal, often passive) To trick, to deceive.
examples: I bought a laptop online but it never arrived. I think I've been had!
You had me alright! I never would have thought that was just a joke.

entries.meaning: (transitive, in the negative, often in continuous tenses) To allow; to tolerate.
examples: The child screamed incessantly for his mother to buy him a toy, but she wasn't having any of it.
I asked my dad if I could go to the concert this Thursday, but he wouldn't have it since it's a school night.

entries.meaning: (transitive, often used in the negative) To believe, buy, be taken in by.
examples: I made up an excuse as to why I was out so late, but my wife wasn't having any of it.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To host someone; to take in as a guest.
examples: Thank you for having me!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To get a reading, measurement, or result from an instrument or calculation.
examples: What do you have for problem two?
I have two contacts on my scope.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a jury) To consider a court proceeding that has been completed; to begin deliberations on a case.
examples: We’ll schedule closing arguments for Thursday, and the jury will have the case by that afternoon.

entries.meaning: (transitive, birdwatching) To make an observation of (a bird species).
(Australia, New Zealand, informal) A fraud or deception; something misleading.
examples: They advertise it as a great deal, but I think it's a bit of a have.
